div.p: Greetings, Reverend Father, this evening, having returned home from a little walk, I found letters from Mr. Martinengo on the table; since there was someone to deliver them, I quickly enclosed them in this letter of mine, without copying them, as there was no time. Therefore, you will return a copy at some point. The matter is of little importance, I admit; but all these collected things can still be of some help. We are very anxiously awaiting news about the French affairs.

Is Condé conducting himself well? Various rumors are spreading. What is happening with the English, who seem to have little favor returned? We know the German knights have returned; they are owed three months' pay; the German princes are said to have pledged their faith.

Today I discussed many things with a knight, with a black rider, who otherwise has not healed from the wounds; he has bound himself here. He reported everything in good faith, of which he was also a part, as it has been written to us so far; the narration was pleasant. He was under the blood flag, a single horseman; he speaks of a Züricher, named Uli Müller, who was also a single horseman, whose bravery he praises; Uli Müller is not known to me. He attests very highly and dearly that the cuirassiers and riders were defeated before the Confederates were attacked. Therefore, when I let him read their letter to the 5 places after the battle, in which they reported how they stood alone for 2 hours, etc., it was very strange and foreign to him.

He does not seem to be vain. He told me many things about Beza, whose sermons he attended several times; for he is fluent in French. Otherwise, he says that the Brunswickers have kept a preacher from Oberen-Baden from the Confederates, a well-spoken man, said to be named Johannes, but he could not remember the surname. He reported everything else in such a way that it appears he was present at all; for he was among the first who were at Orléans. The one from Portian is said to have accompanied them up to Lothringen and dismissed them there; the outstanding pay is said to be settled for them in Cologne by the upcoming Michaelmas.

These and many other things. Farewell, Reverend Father, with all your family, as happily as possible. All your things have been returned to me; I am most grateful. Written in haste at Chur on the night before the calends of July in the year 1563. Your most observant F[abricius].
To the most esteemed Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his lord and reverend father in Christ. Zurich.
